formattedAddress: Loyola School, 980 Park Avenue St David's Gym, 215 East 94th St Riverside Park, 105th St, New York, NY 10028, USA
adrFormatAddress: Loyola School, 980 Park Avenue St David's Gym, 215 East 94th St Riverside Park, 105th St, New York, NY 10028, USA

originalText.text: Can't express in words how wonderful HOT Volleyball is! It's really tough to find a program that truly cares about kids and real development. Without hesitation HOT is by far the best and you will be so happy you enrolled your child in their programs.

text.text: Can't express in words how wonderful HOT Volleyball is! It's really tough to find a program that truly cares about kids and real development. Without hesitation HOT is by far the best and you will be so happy you enrolled your child in their programs.

originalText.text: As a current high school player here, I've learned some valuable things. But up to a certain extent, the coaches are no longer helpful. I'm a mainly defensive player, and learning how to hit was incredibly difficult because of the coach's non-constructive criticism. With this, I would say that the way hot is advertised is somewhat deceptional. Traci (being the owner of hot) is incredibly helpful, but rarely coaches consistently due to the variety of different classes she teaches. Traci helps players become self-sufficient athletes, while most other coaches at hot tend to produce volleyball players that can't work with their team well enough to play the team sport efficiently.  I also find that alot of the coaches are quite impatient for teachers working with adolescents.  Volleyball is an extremely technical game, and the process of learning it and improving at it requires many mistakes and misinterpretations, and coaches need to be more support of that at hot. Most of the time, coaches notice a mistake in a player's form or technique and tell them the mistake. I've very rarely seen coaches tell players how to improve their form, rather just tell them what to do for the bare minimum.  If your player is someone that wants to be someone that "knows how to play volleyball" or an "average volleyball player" then this is perfect for your player. If your player wants to harness their talents and become an "exceptional volleyball player", then i would personally say that paying upwards of 500$ for most classes is not worth it.

originalText.text: My daughter loves this volleyball clinic, and she has several to compare it to.  Traci Edwards is an excellent instructor and has really developed my daughter's game.  She teaches them skills, corrects their game, gets them in shape, and provides a really fun and encouraging environment.

She teaches them skills, corrects their game, gets them in shape, and provides a really fun and encouraging environment.

originalText.text: Excellent training program for any level of volleyball! My daughters have improved greatly in the HOT program. The coach is knowledgeable and able to teach clearly and efficiently. Highly recommend this program!

text.text: Excellent training program for any level of volleyball! My daughters have improved greatly in the HOT program. The coach is knowledgeable and able to teach clearly and efficiently. Highly recommend this program!

originalText.text: Traci is the most dedicated and passionate coach. She is strict and demanding yet caring and cheerful. She focuses on teaching the required skills to get the girls to the next level.
